a procedure for preventing and treating dental caries using hand instruments and adhesive filling material. Does not require electricity or anesthesia and may be performed in the field by trained healthcare workers or nondental personnel.
See tempering.
subjecting a metal to a given controlled heat, followed by controlled sudden or gradual cooling to develop the desired qualities of the metal to the maximal degree.
a process of giving a metal predetermined physical properties by controlled temperature changes.
See anneal.
See capping, indirect pulp.
an association between a health care provider and an individual in which the health care provided to the individual by the health care provider has been ordered by another provider.
in dentistry a schedule of procedures and appointments designed to restore, step by step, the oral health of a patient.
the formal outline of the projected treatment of a patient (e.g., the blueprint from which the dental professional projects treatment).
use of a drug sealed into a root canal to relieve pain or discomfort; not used primarily for its antiseptic value.
the techniques and pharmaceuticals used in removing pulp tissue, sterilizing the root canal, and preparing the root canal for filling.
See treatment, rest.
See anneal.

brand name: found in products such as Colgate Total; drug class: broad spectrum antibacterial agent; action: inhibits enol-acyl protein reductase, leading to loss of type II fatty acid synthesis; use: combined in an oral product to aid in reducing plaque within the oral cavity.
division into three parts or branches, as the three roots of a maxillary first molar.
spasms of the muscles of mastication resulting in the inability to open the oral cavity; often symptomatic of pericoronitis.

a small rounded elevation on the lingual surface of the mandible on either side of the midline near the inferior border of the body of the mandible, serving as a point of insertion for the geniohyoid muscles.
a surgical excision of excessive fibrous or bony tissue in the area of the maxillary tuberosity before the construction of prosthetic appliances.
a swelling. Through usage the term is now synonymous with neoplasm. See also neoplasm.

a benign tumor that develops from odontogenic epithelium and usually surrounds the crown of an impacted tooth; histologically, it is composed of ducts lined by cuboidal or columnar cells. Also known as adenoameloblastoma and ameloblastic adenomatoid tumor.
See carcinoma, adenocystic.
See epithelioma adenoides cysticum.
a central giant cell tumor of the bone; associated with parathyroidism.
a tumor formed about the carotid bifurcation.
a rare condition in which two neoplasms, both growing in the same general area, collide with the tumor elements and become intermingled.
See sarcoma, Ewing’s.
a benign neoplasm of bone, producing resorption and characterized by giant cells.
a benign tumor of the oral soft tissue, most commonly the tongue. Usually of neural origin, these are characterized by the presence of large polygonal cells with a granular cytoplasm.
localized enlargements of the gingivae that have the appearance of neoplasms and are associated with hormonal imbalance during pregnancy. Not a true tumor.
a benign tissue growth made up of inflammatory cells; not a true tumor. The majority of oral growths fall into this category. See also granuloma, neoplasm.
See keratocystic odontogenic tumor.
substances that are often found in elevated levels in the bloodstream, urine, or other bodily tissue when cancer is present in the body.
See carcinoma, mucoepidermoid.
a neoplasm produced from tooth-forming tissue (e.g., odontogenic fibroma, odontogenic myxoma, ameloblastoma). See also calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor.
See carcinoma, basal cell.
See cystadenoma, papillary, lymphomatosum.
a natural body protein with anticancer effects. It is produced in the body in response to the presence of toxic substances, such as bacterial toxins. Adverse effects are toxic shock and cachexia.
the portion of a tooth that lies between its height of contour and the gingivae, only if that portion is of less circumference than the height of contour.
the contour of a cross-section of a residual ridge of dental arch that would prevent the placement of a denture or other prosthesis.
the contour of flasking stone that interlocks to prevent the separation of parts.

the portion of a prepared cavity that creates a mechanical lock or area of retention; may be desirable in a cavity to be filled with gold foil or amalgam but is undesirable in a cavity prepared for a restoration to be cemented.
See gauge, undercut.
an area of the abutment surface suitable for the location of a retentive clasp terminal, which to escape the undercut would be forced to flex and thus generate retention.
an undercut in a residual ridge or soft-tissue covering of a dental arch that would prevent or influence the placement of a removable denture.

the area of an abutment tooth or soft tissue across which a unit of the removable partial denture must pass without interference and hence must be blocked out (filled with wax or clay) before the master cast is duplicated. Use of a surveyor produces a surface that is parallel to the proposed path of a placement and removal.
the act of uniting or the condition of being united (e.g., the result of joining the components of a removable partial denture by connectors).

the accepted mode of conduct and the set of norms, goals, and values binding any social group that serves as a frame of reference for the individual in reaching decisions and achieving a meaningful life.
in the construction of crowns or pontics, a layer of tooth-colored material, usually porcelain or acrylic resin, attached to the surface by direct fusion, cementation, or mechanical retention.

a thin layer of tooth colored material, usually porcelain but sometimes acrylic, that is attached directly to a facial tooth surface using bonding techniques to improve the esthetic appearance of the tooth. techniques to improve the esthetic appearance of the tooth.
See overlap, vertical.
empty or unfilled space.
space not filled with anything solid.
ineffectual; having no legal, binding effect.
one of several esters of fatty acids with higher alcohols, usually monohydric alcohols. Dental waxes are combinations of various types of waxes compounded to provide the desired physical properties.
a hard, pink wax used for making occlusion rims and baseplates for occlusion rims.
a plastic mixture that may contain antiseptic and hemostatic drugs, designed for temporary application to freshly cut bone to prevent hemorrhage and infection.
a soft wax used for boxing impressions.
See burnout, inlay and wax elimination.
a hard, high-melting wax used for control of the melting range of dental waxes.
a composition containing various waxes with controlled properties of thermal expansion and contraction; used in making patterns to determine the shape of metal castings.

the procedure of removing the wax from a wax pattern invested in a mold preparatory to the introduction of another material into the resulting cavity. This may be done by dry heat alone or irrigation with boiling water followed by use of dry heat. Also called wax burnout.
the enlargement of wax patterns to compensate for the shrinkage of gold during the casting process.

a series of waxes, each having different physical properties, used for making a correctable impression of the foundation structures that are to support a denture base. The term indicates that the wax is applied in fluid form as required.
See wax casting.
See blockout.
See pattern, wax.
See template, wax.
the contouring of a wax pattern or the wax base of a trial denture into the desired form. Also called waxing up.
a small, pointed, triangular, contoured piece of wood used to seal the gingival margin of a cavity preparation before placement of a direct restoration.
See penetrometer.
an oral hygiene device made of plastic or wood used to stimulate and clean between teeth.
See effect, wedging.

the product of the gravitational acceleration of one body and the mass of an attracted body; the measurement in pounds and ounces of how heavy an object is. In the metric system, weight (force) is measured in kg × m/sec2.
the sum of the atomic weights of all atoms in a molecule.
a piece of metal varying in shape and weight, attached to a clip that is hung on the bottom of a placed rubber dam to keep the field of operation clear.
See Burlew wheel.
See stone, wheel.
a wire formed by drawing a cast structure through a die; used in dentistry for partial denture clasps and orthodontic appliances.
a form of metal resulting from the swaging, rolling, and drawing of a metal ingot into a desired shape and size.
See wire, wrought.

dryness of the oral cavity resulting from functional or organic disturbances of the salivary glands including obstruction and autoimmune disease (Sjögren’s syndrome) and lack of the normal secretion, most commonly caused by prescribed medications. Dryness, loss of basic environment, and resultant overgrowth of oral microorganisms frequently lead to rampant caries. See also hyposalivation.
the lower-energy circuit in a radiography machine that uses a step-down transformer to lower the line voltage to around 3 volts, just enough to heat the filament and produce an electron cloud.
a radiograph that has a single wavelength or an extremely narrow band of wavelengths.
a low-calorie sweetener that reduces caries activity and the growth and transmission of S. mutans.
See cement, zinc phosphate.
